fields.description:
In the Bitbucket web interface, one can filter the branch list as Active or Merged. I would like to use the REST API to get the list of Merged branches but it seems this is not supported.  I can get a list of branches using the 1.0 API but there does not appear to be anything that indicates if they have been merged or not.

In our workflow we typically use the option to delete branches after they have been merged but occasionally we need to keep the branch for a while or sometimes users simply forget to delete branch.   In either case it would be nice to have a way to remind users of any merged branches they have lying around. I was going to write a simple script to do this using the REST API but the merge status is not accessible.

Can the merge status be added to the API?

Thanks,\\
Phil
fields.summary: Get list of merged branches using REST API

fields.description:
This is a wish-list item.

I would like to check in my code to my bitbucket repo and, once there, run a cloud-based Doxygen against that code.

I supply the Doxyfile.  You supply the doxygen.

The output of Doxygen (HTML) would go to a static HTML site (cloud storage).. perhaps even to my project's own "landing page"

Whatever HTML was generated, it should probably be tagged in accordance with the revision of the code from which it was generated.  I don't see the need to support MULTIPLE doxygen outputs.  I'd be happy enough with just the "latest" (if such a concept even makes sense in a multi-branch world).

Does anyone else see value in having bitbucket provide doxygen-as-a-service?
fields.summary: offer Doxygen-As-A-Service

fields.description: Building images doesn't seem to make use of any kind of cache, am I able to configure this in anyway so that the same image is not pulled for each build?
fields.summary: Is it possible to cache a download image where the version is not latest

fields.summary: Service Integration with FogBugz no longer possible.

fields.description:
Hi there,

I want to do that pipeline will working automatically when I pull request and find [this|https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/43214039/can-i-trigger-bitbucket-pipeline-with-pull-request].

That way I could setup pipelines to only run tests on the master branch, and if anyone creates a pull request to the master branch, those also get run through pipelines.

This might help save some minutes.
fields.summary: Trigger Bitbucket pipeline with pull request

fields.description: Resending a webhook request no longer works. I used be able to resent any missed requests if the listening server was down. Now this always fails. Screen capture attached.
fields.summary: Request resend failed

fields.description:
A relative link in a README works well only when viewed from the source view and only when the README itself is actively being viewed.

But the README is actually rendered in 3 places: the repo overview, the source overview and the README file source page. In the first 2 situations, the browser sends you to an invalid page. One solution to this problem is to prefix relative links with the repo's source view (including hash etc.).
fields.summary: Relative links in README often 404

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a PR contains a commit with a submodule rename, then the diff is not showing in Bitbucket UI

h3. Steps to Reproduce
{code}
#!python

$ git init
$ echo 'hello world' > foo
$ git add foo
$ git commit -m 'initial commit'
$ git submodule add url_of_another_repo
$ git commit -m 'add submodule'
$ git remote add origin url_of_repo_in_bitbucket
$ git push origin master

$ git checkout -b branch1
$ git mv name_of_submodule name_of_submodule2
$ git commit -m 'rename submodule'
$ git push --set-upstream origin branch1
{code}

Create a PR from branch1 to master branch in Bitbucket

h3. Expected Results
The PR shows the diff in the Overview page

h3. Actual Results
An error is shown: !1009498585-Screen%20Shot%202017-03-20%20at%2017.58.48.png|thumbnail!\\
and the diff is not loading
fields.summary: If a PR contains a commit with a submodule rename, then the diff is not showing in Bitbucket UI

fields.description:
Ideally, when I manage access to repositories and groups in my organization, I need to make sure that I don't accidentally add someone from outside of the organization. Currently, BitBucket seems to focus on allowing me to add _ANYONE_ from anywhere on bitbucket, and doesn't help much with controlling that.

For example, when adding members to the organization, I would like to have some kind of verification of their account - seeing names, possibly picture, etc. Currently, if I did that, I only see a little dropdown for autocomplete which is supposed to be enough for me to verify that this is indeed the right user.

Similarly, when I add users to groups within my team, I would like to ALWAYS prefer users from the organization, and have some kind of warning if I add a user to a group (or a repository) from outside of the organization.
fields.summary: Provide additional controls for group & repository management in teams

fields.description:
Currently there isn't any option to add a link to the parent repository from a forked repository manually.

The only way to link them is to create the fork from Bitbucket.

This feature would be useful for importing repositories from other sites where the fork did not happen in Bitbucket Cloud.
fields.summary: Ability to manually link forked repository to parent repository

fields.description:
These are the environment variables we can use now: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/environment-variables-794502608.html

I'd also like to have access to the person who triggered the Pipeline, either the Git user who committed/pushed the changes, or the Bitbucket user who manually triggered the Pipeline.

Ideally this would be provided in the format {{Full name <email@address.com>}}, similar to Git.

_Original request_

This ticket also requested the Git commit short hash, but that is easily retrievable either via git directly ({{git log --format=%h -n1}}) or by trimming down the BITBUCKET_COMMIT env var ({{echo $BITBUCKET_COMMIT | cut -c1-7}}).
fields.summary: Environment variable for user who triggered build

fields.description:
The screenshot shows a search for the word "eina" in the issue tracker of a project of mine.

All of the following searches should return one or more results:

"eina escollir", "eina admin", "eina place_id", "eina child", "escollir referència", "admin escollir"

NONE of them does.

This is pathetic. If I cannot trust the search engine to find issues whose very titles contain the keywords, the search is completely useless.
fields.summary: Improve issue search
Tag created over Bitbucket web interface does not start pipeline

fields.description:
When attempting to install the Git Flow (https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/net.collabsoft.plugins.stash.gfc/cloud/overview)  Bitbucket Cloud add-on directly from the Marketplace the add-on isn't found in BB Cloud when the user is re-directed there:

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Select the _Try for Free_ button on the Marketplace listing
# Select _Get it now_ for BB Cloud version. (https://bitbucket.org/repo/LboRq/images/494513950-Screen%20Shot%202017-03-13%20at%2010.00.04.png)
# User is redirected to BB Cloud but now results for the add-on are found in the integrations section. URL is {noformat}\\
https://bitbucket.org/account/user/chparker2/addon-directory?addon=net.collabsoft.plugins.stash.gfc\\
{noformat}

The add-on is in the registry as it can be seen in _Find Integrations_, other add-ons are working as expected.

*Note* Created from Marketplace ticket:

https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/AMKT-19867
fields.summary: Selecting the Get it now on the Marketplace for the Git Flow Bitbucket Cloud add-on leads to a blank page

fields.description:
We would like to have pipeline working with specific branch. The reason for this is because our workflow requires each new feature to be developed within its specific brunch, deployed to test server, tested. Only after that we merge it in master.

Currently, when running custom Pipeline builds, the default variable $BITBUCKET_BRANCH does not read the current branch.
fields.summary: Running custom Pipeline for a branch does not run with branch context

fields.description:
when i download a tag. folder inside zip comes with "usermae-reponame-somenumbrs"\\
is it possible to give parameter in URL to  for folder name.\\
i was searching for solution but not bale to find.

if you allow i can do it but i don't know how i can contribute.

Thanks.
fields.summary: allow Folder Name parameter on tag download.

fields.description: I'd like a way to sort and filter Pipelines by various properties, for example to find the latest successful pipeline for a specific branch of a repository.
fields.summary: REST API: Ability to sort and filter Pipelines by branch and other properties

fields.description:
In our group there are multiple developers who need to be notified about Pull Request(PR) and only one or two who have a significant role(aka lead developer in proj) and actually need to be approvers.

As a way around we need to keep "Primary approvers" on the PR comment.\\
Proposed to keep the list of people who will be a watchers but not approvers created /edited in PR.

As watcher concept is already in place the story has a meaning of enabling watcher list edit during creation and edit.
fields.summary: Optional reviewers/watchers list for a pull request

fields.description:
When viewing source page of the repository, some users will encounter the error message on 500 HTTP : Something went wrong.

As current workaround, you can view the Source Page by following the steps below if it helps:

# Navigate to _Commit_ page
# Click on the latest commit hash
# Click any _View File_ button in the commit
# Navigate to the repository's root folder

This should temporarily allow you to access your Source Page directly without going through the above steps again

Do let us know, and provide the error code below so that we can track the number of issues.
fields.summary: Could not access source page, resulting in 500 HTTP error

fields.description:
It's a nice feature that projects have a language logo but dlojure doesn't have one.  kind of feeling left out.

Pick [one at by googling|https://www.google.com/search%3Fq%3Dclojure%2Blogo%26source%3Dlnms%26tbm%3Disch%26sa%3DX%26ved%3D0ahUKEwi3lvj6uNzSAhUk7oMKHcADAlsQ_AUICCgB%26biw%3D1388%26bih%3D725] or use http://van-clj.github.io/logo.png
fields.summary: logo for clojure projects

fields.description: In the event that there are branch restrictions / merge checks, it would be nice to have an admin override (similar to the option in Github)
fields.summary: Create an "admin only" merge button for pull requests

fields.description:
Hi there,\\
I can't add user to my repository even when I'm the only person using the repo.
fields.summary: Can't add user to repo

fields.description:
When viewing the commit history of a repository by default the diff is shown for every changed file. But there is a button "Show file" which shows the complete file.

I miss something like this for the wiki commit history. For the wiki, only the diff is displayed, the "View file" (or "View page") button is missing. Would be handy if it could be added.
fields.summary: Complete view of a page for every commit

fields.description:
I would like the ability to run some custom commands on fail builds that happens on pipelines.\\
Right now, our pipeline is running multiple steps including connection to third party servers/services.\\
Sometimes this connection fails, however all other previous steps were executed and there is no way of rolling back the changes that were made.

Would it be possible to add a trigger to configuration that would pass the number of the step that failed, so that a custom script would run which would roll back any necessary changes.

Configuration could look like:

{code}
#!yml

pipelines:
  branches:
    development:
      - step:
          script:
            - step 1
            - step 2
            - step 3
            - step 4
      - rollback:
          script:
            - step 1
{code}
fields.summary: Rollback commands on fail builds

fields.description:
We've identified an issue where alpine based images may fail to resolve domain names.

We believe this is associated with https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/30215 and https://github.com/gliderlabs/docker-alpine/issues/8
fields.summary: Pipelines using alpine based images have trouble resolving DNS names

fields.description:
All retries fail immediately with a generic pop up at the top of the screen.\\
!3394203588-Screen%20Shot%202017-03-15%20at%203.27.02%20PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Webhook retries are failing.

fields.description:
When clicking the "Resend Request" button for a webhook request (don't matter, pass/fail/whatever) I get a toaster popup saying request failed with the following in the javascript console.

{code}
#!

index.js:222 POST https://bitbucket.org/!api/internal/repositories/rw_grim/convey/hooks/%7Bfc…deff52b96661%7D/requests/%7B9694e257-5a2b-4fe0-8752-bfa6efe007fc%7D/resend 400 ()
s @ index.js:222
o @ index.js:50
(anonymous) @ connect-request.js:20
i @ connect-request.js:19
a @ request-detail-api.jsx:13
(anonymous) @ PublisherMethods.js:95
n @ PublisherMethods.js:44
i.emit @ index.js:116
trigger @ PublisherMethods.js:113
(anonymous) @ PublisherMethods.js:155
a @ setImmediate.js:40
o @ setImmediate.js:69
n @ setImmediate.js:109
VM129:2 Unexpected token s in JSON at position 0
{code}
fields.summary: Webhook replays are not working

fields.description:
I have a pretty good idea of how long my build should take. If for some reason it takes longer (network issue, a bug in the build script or an infinite loop in some test code), I'd like to avoid it hanging and have it fail within a timeout that I can set. This avoids eating up build minutes from waiting until the full 2 hour limit.

e.g. I expect my build to take no longer than 5 minutes. If it takes longer than 5 minutes, it should just fail.

Ideally, this would be param that can be set in the bitbucket-pipelines.yml.
fields.summary: Have a customizable timeout

fields.description:
Pipelines started closing idle Maven connections that are idle for more than 5 minutes after the last infrastructure update. This affects any build which is running Maven and takes longer than this amount of time because such build will fail with 'connection reset socket exception'.

Some plugins in the Maven lifecycle are triggered after running integration tests and the only workaround is to force Maven to use a new connection on every request using 'mvn -Dmaven.wagon.http.pool=false clean install'. This, however, affects the build time.

I would like Pipelines to work the same way as they worked before because changes like these are either polluting the build yaml script with ugly workarounds or causing previously passing builds to fail for no reason.
fields.summary: Pipelines kills idle Maven connections after 5 minutes

fields.description:
I finally got it to work by using the java image, but I am unhappy about the fact I have no control over the java version being used (always using the newest version may result in bugs), and then manually load my packages. I think the entire thing could be easier and more flexible in terms of version picking.

Here is my pipeline script:

{code}
# This is a sample build configuration for Java – Maven.
# Check our guides at https://confluence.atlassian.com/x/zd-5Mw for more examples.
# Only use spaces to indent your .yml configuration.
# -----
# You can specify a custom docker image from Docker Hub as your build environment.
image: java

pipelines:
  default:
    - step:
        script:
          - cd PeersReview/
          - apt-get update
          - apt-get --assume-yes install nodejs
          - apt-get --assume-yes install npm
          - ln -s /usr/bin/nodejs /usr/bin/node
          - node -v
          - npm -v
          - apt-get --assume-yes install maven
          - npm install
          - npm install -g grunt-cli
          - npm install grunt-npm-install --save-dev
          - npm install --save-dev grunt-shell
          - npm install grunt-shell-spawn2 --save-dev
          - npm install grunt-maven
          - grunt --gruntfile MavenGruntFile.js
          - ls -l ROOTProd.war
{code}
fields.summary: Mixing mvn and java difficult

fields.description: PNGs that customers upload using Git LFS are displayed in the preview as JPGs and lose transparency and other attributes making the preview less useful
fields.summary: Bitbucket converts *.png to *.jpeg under diff view, which changes image attributes

fields.description:
How to recreate:

* Create private issue tracker
* Do some updates (so they show under your recent activity in overview)
* Disable issue tracker, log out.

Result: you should see these private issues now appear on your public timeline under recent activity
fields.summary: Private issue activities are made public after issue tracker is disabled.

fields.description: When creating a pull request to review code, it seems that users are unable to push up a new branch without first merging this branch first.
fields.summary: Mercurial: Unable to push named branch without merging

fields.description: Lately when I try to view differences side-by-side during a pull request code review, nothing loads on the right side.
fields.summary: Side-By-Side diff not showing one side

fields.description:
If a user uses the {{access_token}} query parameter, and the API either redirects or generates links, then these links currently don't get a copy of the {{access_token}} query parameter. An unsuspecting dev would be confused by this and not figure out why the responses to the followed links are forbidden.

Bitbucket does a good job in its documentation of asking users to prefer other OAuth mechanisms like the Authorization header, which do not suffer from these problems, so that's good and acknowledged, but the situation could be made better.
fields.summary: access_token query parameter could be added to redirects and HATEOAS links

fields.description:
I don't know about the rest of you, but the overview page is NOT how I use Bitbucket.

I've watched other team members at my company use Bitbucket and it's always click the Bitbucket logo in the top left and then click the repositories tab.  Please default back to repositories or provide a setting to configure the default tab.  The overview tab is not as useful as you think it is.

At least during the beta for the overview tab you gave us the option to put repositories as the default page.  How about restoring that option?
fields.summary: Please restore option to make Repositories list default page

fields.description:
After selecting a deployment group to AWS, a link should be available that will redirect to the deployments page on Code Deploy.\\
Now the link is missing.
fields.summary: Missing link after deployment to AWS on Pipelines.

fields.description:
Every so often, when someone agrees with us on this thread:\\
BCLOUD-4588\\
I get an email to say "+1", what a good idea it is, and Atlassian should definitely do that etc.

As the issue is marked "Won't Fix" (let's say, for argument's sake, due to potential cannibalism with the Jira product - a reasonable position for Atlassian to take), the feature request will never happen.

The net result is that I receive a drip, drip, drip via e-mail, reminding me how disappointed I am in the "Won't Fix" decision how my desire to improve the product is pointless, the Universe is out to get me etc.

It would be better if Atlassian's "Won't Fix" discussions are shut down entirely (removing the community's ability to comment once more about how this request is 5 years old and STILL nothing has been done etc.).

In this way, neither Atlassian nor its users are constantly reminded of the (good? / bad? - let's say "bad") decision and the eternally soul-crushing and heart-rending disappointment wrought by the Atlassian product team.

Alternative fix: Reverse the "Won't Fix" decision on 4588.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Issues: Closeable comment threads

fields.description:
Elixir support for Bitbucket has been around for a few years (see issues BCLOUD-3848 and BCLOUD-7852) which is great!

However, one thing that seems to be missing still, is support for Elixir syntax highlighting in Snippets. The ".ex" extension defaults to "Eiffel" instead and Elixir doesn’t show up in the language dropdown.

It would be really cool and I’d find it tremendously useful if you could add Elixir support to Snippets :-)
fields.summary: Support Elixir for Snippets
Build resulting from merge of pull request with "close branch" ticked fails

fields.description:
I noticed this bug when solving [this issue|BCLOUD-13909] and specifically in [this comment in that issue|BCLOUD-13909].

The problem is that the authentication methods used for /api and /!api are not identical and a user authenticated for the former may not be authenticated for the latter.

The problem also exists for redirects.
fields.summary: Links produced in API response for /api refer to /!api

fields.description: Images parsed from root is shown broken in Wiki, but correctly displays in preview.
fields.summary: Images from root is broken in Wiki.

fields.description: When creating a tag using Bitbucket UI, the tag dos not contain the information compared to a tag created locally.
fields.summary: Missing info when creating tags using UI.

fields.description:
The documentation for every payloads [1] does not have an entity sample for links.  I can figure it out from the json of course, but docs would be nice ;)

[1] https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/event-payloads-740262817.html#EventPayloads-entity_repository
fields.summary: event payload documentation missing entity sample for links

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you add a username alias to a repository's Settings >> Username aliases, it takes ~1 hour for the commit with that alias to show the proper user.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In your git config, change your email to one that is not linked with any Bitbucket account
# Make a commit to a repo of yours with that email
# Push this commit to a repo in Bitbucket
# Open the repo in Bitbucket >> Commits
# The Author will show as Unknown
# Click on the Author field of the commit, you will be prompted to add a username alias for this email
# The _Username aliases_ page of the repo will open
# Add the alias in there and map it to your username

h3. Expected Results
If you go to the Commits page of the repo, your user should show as this commit's Author

h3. Actual Results
This particular commit shows the author as Unknown for up to an hour -- only after ~1 hour the mapping seems to work properly
fields.summary: Adding an email alias to a repo takes up to an hour to start working

fields.description: As a user, I'd like to find the issues I have created.
fields.summary: Search issues by creator

fields.description:
The default comments in ssh-keygen(1) keys (user@host) aren’t as useful as they could be, and together with the “added” column, a column for key types would reduce my desire to give each of my keys a custom comment.

A key type column that consists of the first word of each key (like “ssh-rsa” or “ssh-ed25‌519”) would be a viable start, but a column that says “RSA (4096 bits)” or “ECDSA (P-256)” or “DSA (1024 bits)” ^ or “Ed25519” would really tickle my fancy.

^ you could omit the “(1024 bits)” for now, because SSH (as of RFC 4253) is tightly coupled to the FIPS 186-2 version of DSA, where keys must be of that length
fields.summary: SSH keys: add a column for the types of the user’s keys

fields.description: For any company, I imagine there are use cases where you want some automated commits to a repo not to be tied to a specific human being (e.g. a git tag when code is deployed by an automated process) and also credentials tied to that process.  Right now the plan appears to be to charge for that user. $2/month is not a big deal, but think ideally one would not be charged for that.
fields.summary: suggestion: no charge for "system" user

fields.description:
We sometimes commit a few times in rapid succession - outpacing pipelines. We are set to only pull to a depth of 1 as we were finding it slow pulling a larger depth. Would it be possible to skip rather than fail the pipeline if the commit hash isn't found within the git pull? The latest version will be in the queue for a pipeline build anyway!

Thanks

Joe
fields.summary: Pipelines fail if build is not for latest commit

fields.description:
SSH keys that use DSA aren’t broken, but their days are numbered:

* SSH is tightly coupled to 1024-bit DSA keys, thanks to [RFC 4253|https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4253] and [FIPS 186-2|http://csrc.nist.gov/publications/fips/archive/fips186-2/fips186-2.pdf]
* there’s [more than one way|https://www.ietf.org/mail-archive/web/secsh/current/msg00848.html] to increase that limit in the wild, and [no standard in sight|https://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-ietf-curdle-rsa-sha2-03#section-6]
* DSA has [more points of failure|https://security.stackexchange.com/a/112818] than RSA, and seems to be [closer to broken|https://security.stackexchange.com/a/46781]
* Debian has banned its developers from using them [since 2008|https://lists.debian.org/debian-devel-announce/2008/05/msg00004.html]
* OpenSSH has disabled DSA in its client and server [since 2015|https://www.openssh.com/releasenotes.html#7.0]

Some ideas which may or may not be feasible:

* refuse to allow users to add SSH keys that use DSA
* use notifications to ask users with DSA keys to remove them
* disable DSA keys across the board at some point in the future

The third option should be done with caution if at all, or it could fuck the customer by breaking their automated processes, if they have any that rely on such keys.

Every cryptographic algorithm has a shelf life, and new flaws can bring an algorithm’s shelf life forward to $(date) in an instant. There might be some value in keeping some of this “key deprecation infrastructure” around — RSA, ECDSA, and Ed25519 will one day be in DSA’s shoes.
fields.summary: SSH keys: refuse to add new DSA keys and suggest or push users with DSA keys to remove them

fields.description:
As a developer I'd like to receive not only negative feedback during a code-review.\\
As the case of Facebook clearly shows, the platform has to make it easier to express good feedback than negative feedback (pressing a like button is easier then writing a comment) to make the balance between the two more representative of the reality (people with negative feelings seem more determined to express their opinion, so you have to lower the bar for the positive feedback to observe it).\\
A Code Review is a best practice. But is also a bit frustrating and emotionally depleting experience. Sure, one should be detached from the code authored; sure, one should strive to accept constructive critique, the same way we handle error messages and warning messages.\\
But wouldn't life of developers be better, if the compiler said "Well done!" on successful compilation, and colleagues could express their awe for a cool line of code effortlessly?\\
Perhaps, then the profession of a developer would attract and sustain a more diverse range o personalities.\\
I propose a simple feature in witch hovering over a line, displays a clickable "thumb up" icon, which simply gives a positive feedback to the author.
fields.summary: like button for lines in pull-request changeset

fields.description:
As a new developer I'd like to search through PR comments to gain knowledge about best practices. A lot of knowledge about the project, language, conventions etc. is shared among participants of code review, and then it's kinda lost, while the PR gets resolved.\\
Consider a long discussion between senior developers about a particularly difficult piece of code - it often contains insights that would benefit someone new in the project years after the discussion took place.
fields.summary: search in pull-request discussions

fields.description: It would be very nice if environment variables which are defined from respository or account level were printed out in the build setup step (for example JAVA_OPTS).
fields.summary: Print environment variables in Build setup step

fields.description:
As seen on https://github.com/git-lfs/git-lfs/releases:

"Deprecations:

Git LFS v2.0.0 also drops support for the legacy API in v0.5.0. If you're still\\
using LFS servers on the old API, you'll have to stick to v1.5.6."

*Workaround*: Either downgrading to Git-LFS 1.5.5 or using SSH remotes should work
fields.summary: Git-LFS 2.0+ fails with HTTPS authentication

fields.description:
Go to a repo in BB -> Settings -> Set a "Main Branch " -> Save settings.\\
Go to the Branches on the Left -> Create Branch -> Branch From select any branch but the one that you set as a "Main Branch " -> Name your branch ->Create.\\
Now click on the Branch name you just created a see that the "Parent branch" for your created branch is actually showing as a Main Branch and not the one you selected as to branch from.

Expected behavior:  to see the "Parent branch"  as the branch name from which you branched out
fields.summary: Repo branches doesn't correctly show the "parent" branch, instead defaulting to the "Main Branch"

fields.description:
I would like to know the name of the user that manually started a pipeline (in an environment variable).

The same variable could be used to report the user that triggered a re-run of any build.
fields.summary: User name that triggered build

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When _User A_ makes a pull request and _User B_ merges it, BitBucket uses _User A_ as the commit author for the merge commit which supposed to be _User B_ who is the one that performed merged.\\
This affects the actions triggered in JIRA by the smart commit message which shows the merge are done by _User A_ instead of _User B_

Sample Image\\
!3303702193-MergePR.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: PR Author listed as commit author instead of the User that merged

fields.description:
Several of my team members observed that they stopped receiving email notifications for code reviews on their commits in BitBucket.\\
This is disrupting our development workflow.

I can provide more detail info if needed.
fields.summary: Email notifications for code reviews stopped working

fields.description:
https://bitbucket.org/issueinc/issues/

{code}
#!shell
$ git count-objects -vH
count: 17
size: 68.00 KiB
in-pack: 28752
packs: 1
size-pack: 1.07 GiB
prune-packable: 0
garbage: 0
size-garbage: 0 bytes
{code}

whereas 2.8GB on page https://bitbucket.org/issueinc/issues/admin
fields.summary: SOS: incorrect git repo size is incorrect

fields.description:
Using the response format of [an issue|https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%257Busername%257D/%257Brepo_slug%257D/issues/%257Bissue_id%257D] as a reference:

Many items start with {{all of:}} as if anyone would expecting a {{some of:}} unless explicitly stated. How does this help readability?

The first item of objects & sub-objects is an {{object}} of type {{string *}}, though the real response has no such object, rather it has a normal property called {{type}} with a fixed string value. The expected value is not obvious (it's in a low-visibility, grey comment), and may not even be correct (the example mentions an {{account}} object but this is {{reporter}} in a real response with a {{type}} of {{user}}).

Some items show {{...}} instead of the expected contents, like issue->repository->links.

Some response properties may be {{null}} but these are not identified in your examples.

I understand that you're trying to provide more info about values than a [literal example|https://developer.github.com/v3/issues/#get-a-single-issue] (like listing potential issue {{priority}} values) but, at the moment, it's more legible to make a few test requests to see the actual structure of a response.
fields.summary: API examples format is unnecessarily complex and has some field name errors

fields.description:
When an user using a screen reader wants to assign group/user privileges in a repository admin area, the read/write/admin choices are not announced as checkboxes and the state is also unknown.\\
Tested with latest NVDA on Firefox 51 on Windows 10 64-bit.
fields.summary: User privilege checkboxes not announced as checkboxes with NVDA

fields.description:
h1. Case:
# open pull-request
# launch comment editor for line#1
# click "Preview" in editor (top-right corner)
# submit
# launch comment editor for line#2

h1. expected:
top-right corner btn should have text "preview"

h1. what's wrong:
it still contains "edit" text
fields.summary: Fix: comment editor state

fields.description:
Could show add any icon, that would notify about conflicts in pull-requests, or add a filter?\\
would be useful to watch developers for PR conflicts

PS: should be used only for opened
fields.summary: Notify on pull-request list page about conflicts

fields.description:
Hello,

We've had a PR that was conflicted with the branch it was supposed to be merged to.\\
Branch diff showed about +2 - 5 commits yet declining the PR resulted in massive JIRA update.

Commits tab was listing whole project history and that whole history was pushed back to JIRA.

The issue occurred at about 14:00 GMT+1.
fields.summary: Declining a PR resulted in massive JIRA update for thousands of issues

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a build exceeds the memory limit in Pipelines, the users see a 'Build memory limit exceeded' error. However, the build continues to run after the step that had the memory issue, and it's difficult for users to figure out the exact point of failure.

h3. Suggested Solution
In cases where the memory limit is exceeded, add more information on the logs about the process that caused this.
fields.summary: When a Pipelines build exceeds the memory limit, add more information in the log about the process that caused this

fields.description: In the commits tab of a pull request, the commits behind does not show the branch name, showing only an empty space.
fields.summary: In pull requests, commits behind does not show branch name.

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:\\
select a team Name on Settings drop down -> Update team Name to say "TestTeam March 6" -> Update -> team name updates on drop down to "TestTeam March 6" -> now browse to another team or account on drop down, and then go back to the the same team again "TestTeam March 6" and open the Team Settings page -> you will see that the team name on the List drop down remained as "TestTeam March 6"  but the Team name on the right side under Team name now says only "TestTeam"\\
When the team name has a "space" after updating the team name, browse away to a user and come back to that same team everything after space is dropped in the team name\\
This behavior is consistent between Google Chrome and Firefox
fields.summary: When the team name has a "space" - everything after a space gets dropped

fields.description:
Bitbucket HipChat integration is currently broken and not correctly sending "build status" (aka "commit status") to HipChat rooms.

We're working on a fix for this and aim to have it fixed within 24 hours.
fields.summary: Pipelines not sending HipChat notifications

fields.description:
Unclear presentation of responses of the APIs in the documentation makes it unusable to determine its usage.

Consider {{https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Busername%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/forks}}\\
There's no {{owner}} property. But there is one in the actual response. Compare\\
{{https://web.archive.org/web/20160310104905/https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/fork-resource-813893008.html}}\\
which actually has the {{owner}} property in it. If we were setting up our API integration from scratch today, instead of when those were the official docs, it would take us far longer, because the automatically-generated docs are not only hard to read, but wrong.
fields.summary: API v2 docs are missing response information

fields.description: There is no way to clear the 'Recently Viewed' for both projects and repositories in the UI.
fields.summary: Option to clear recently viewed projects/repositories
Unable to filter branches using api.

fields.description:
Hi,

I've just noticed (2017-03-06) that my repo's documention page http://cfpython.bitbucket.org/ redirects to https://bitbucket.org/ rather than rendering https://bitbucket.org/cfpython/cfpython.bitbucket.org/src/master/index.html, which it has always done in the past - has something changed?

Thanks.
fields.summary: Repo documentation page redirects to https://bitbucket.org/

fields.description:
It would be super useful to be able to ssh into a failed build container.

Instead of current fix, commit, push, wait, debug, repeat workflow, just ssh in, do the necessary, take fixes back to pipeline.yml.
fields.summary: ssh into pipeline containers

fields.description:
Please add commit info (username, comment, branch, sha-key) into [build status created|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/event-payloads-740262817.html#EventPayloads-Buildstatuscreated] and [build status updated|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/event-payloads-740262817.html#EventPayloads-Buildstatusupdated] webhook payload.

Currently, only uri to commit is present, and it's not trivial to get commit info (I need to give some access credentials and make request back to my repo).
fields.summary: Add commit info into build status created/updated webhooks

fields.description:
Hi,\\
I've created a (new) testing repository with some larger binaries tracked as lfs files. I've followed the documentation from https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/git-lfs#creating-new-repository

Adding and committing the files locally goes fine. However, the push to the bitbucket.org server fails:

$ git push\\
Git LFS: (0 of 1 files) 5.00 MB / 5.00 MB\\
Authentication required: Authorization error: https://bitbucket.org/%7B%7D/%7Bceab775b-2209-4f4e-8edc-d884a5397085%7D/info/lfs/object/verify?upload_id=e435ab36-e3fe-414b-b896-2c32402f6ea1\\
Check that you have proper access to the repository\\
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://basmevissen@bitbucket.org/emcodev/test_git_lfs.git'

I've made the repo public in an attempt to solve my auth errors, but that did not really help:

$ git push\\
Git LFS: (0 of 1 files) 5.00 MB / 5.00 MB\\
Fatal error: Server error: https://bitbucket.org/%7B%7D/%7Bceab775b-2209-4f4e-8edc-d884a5397085%7D/info/lfs/object/verify?upload_id=8841f4a1-28d6-4091-9c9e-f8f625358d11

Errors logged to /home/bas/Workspace/emcodev/test_git_lfs/.git/lfs/objects/logs/20170305T164905.768079534.log\\
Use {{git lfs logs last}} to view the log.\\
error: failed to push some refs to 'https://basmevissen@bitbucket.org/emcodev/test_git_lfs.git'

Host info:\\
Centos 7 x86_64\\
git-lfs/2.0.0 (GitHub; linux amd64; go 1.8; git 540e90b)\\
git version 1.8.3.1

Any idea what is going on?
fields.summary: git push of repo using lfs fails

fields.description: When team member creates a new repository in the team, it's best that Team administrator has the option to choose to get the email notification about the new repository information.
fields.summary: Customer Request: Ability to receive notification when team member create a new repo

fields.description:
We use the Bitbucket source plugin in Jenkins which works great and it is very popular.

The problem we have is that when scanning the Bitbucket team repos for branches containing Jenkinsfiles we hit the rate limit. We have over 300 repos in our team and we want new repos to be added to Jenkins as fast as possible. The plugin works by pulling the teams all pull requests and branches to search for Jenkinsfiles.

This could be handles more efficiently if Bitbucket teams have webhooks for repo/branch creation and commits to repos in the team.
fields.summary: Add Team repository webhooks

fields.description:
When a smart commit begins to span multiple lines when using git bash, it stops at the first line.

*Commit example:*

{code}
#!plaintext
Fix: export credentials test.

 CHAP-503 #in-progress #time 30min running tests off of develop branch
 and running ignored tests to ensure validity. Fixed export credentials.
 #comment Fixed the export credential test. The code had changed and
 so the test no longer accounted for that. I don't think it needs to be
 ignored any longer. Checks for file existance before and after. I don't
 think we can actually test the response streamfile functionality. Could
 be wrong tho.
{code}

*Result:*

* CHAP-503 is moved to in-progress (good)
* work log entry is made: "#time 30min running tests off of develop branch" (bad)
* rest of work log comment is lost (bad)
* Comment is never created (bad)
fields.summary: multiple smart commit commands from windows gitbash commit fail to work.

fields.description:
When we do a Repo ownership transfer , the person who did the transfer will have a banner on that repo screen to indicate that the transfer of the ownership to another user is pending.\\
Would be nice to have a similar Banner when the person to whom the transfer is intended for gets the same banner to Notify them that they have a pending Repo transfer to accept.
fields.summary: Repo Transfer to have a Banner added to the account that has a pending invitation to accept transfer (BBCDEV-4909)

fields.description:
Hi guys,

I do like the human readable '2 months ago' format, but every now an then I would like to find out the exact date & time a build ran. Would it be possible to add this information somewhere in the interface?

Thanks,

H.
fields.summary: Add (UTC) timestamp to pipeline overview or pipeline result / details

fields.description:
When a user tries to transfer a repository to another user, they get a pop up window where they need to enter the recipient. It's not specified whether they should enter a username or an email address, however it will only work for usernames. Some users will enter an email address, click *Transfer* and keep waiting, because they don't get any error message that email addresses are not allowed.

It would be nice to advice them to enter a username instead of email or display an error if the operation couldn't go through.
fields.summary: 'Transfer repository ownership' does not validate usernames

fields.description:
In certain scenarios, Git may treat binary files as text files which unloads large amount of data during diff.\\
This increases the load on the browser.

Would like to have some functionality on the UI to mitigate this problem.
fields.summary: Allow users to override filetype determined by Git (text vs binary)

fields.description:
"Create branch" "Branch from" no longer selects "main branch" by default; instead it selects the alphabetically first branch, not the "main branch".

This is definitely a big source of error for users.
fields.summary: "Create branch" "Branch from" no longer selects "main branch" by default; instead it selects the alphabetically first branch, not the "main branch".

fields.description: When I open a user page in bitbucket I should see a list of recent (open / merged) pull requests that user has submitted for any project of which we are both members / is public
fields.summary: Teammate pull request activity on user page

fields.description: It would be nice to be able to filter the view of pipelines jobs by custom pipeline so that if you are using custom pipelines to do deployments, you could easily see a history for that deployment.
fields.summary: Filter for custom pipelines on pipelines page

fields.description:
Many customers encounter an issue with hitting our API limit on the number of requests. We are aware that the throttling limits are put in place for security and performance.\\
What would be nice is to have is the ability to see how many requests you have already submitting to know if you will hit a limit next and to have an idea what the intervals should be to prevent service interruption.
fields.summary: Add the ability to track number of API requests for hitting throttling limit purposes

fields.description:
Bitbucket renders UTF-{16,32}-{BE,LE} files in the source view, but in the diff view it fails. The reason is that git itself treats utf-16,32 as binary.

----
Implementation notes:

It is possible to use the {{textconv}} option when using {{format-patch}} (which is what BB uses to generate the diff view), with an option similar to {{'iconv -f utf-16 -t utf-8'}} and hence show a human readable patch.
fields.summary: UTF-16 and UTF-32 files don't show up in the diff (BBCDEV-9261)

fields.description: When creating a branch with the bitbucket interface, the default used to be to branch from the main branch.  Now, it seems to be choosing the first one alphabetically.
fields.summary: Create branch default behavior changed

fields.description: Want to view the repositories in my Bitbucket account for making starred/favorites.
fields.summary: Cannot see the list of projects I have access to in BitBucket

fields.description: We have two different branches in our project. So when we try to merge these two branches it's showing an error that "Unable to merge. This field is required". It is not even showing which field. Please help regarding this. Otherwise, our code won't updated to our live site.
fields.summary: Unable to merge

fields.description: After changing update repository details name* fields "Recent activity" commit links not working. It shows the previous link.
fields.summary: Update Repository Details Bug

fields.description:
By design the 'Team API Key' feature is depricated and was replaced by 'App password' feature at user-level. (as told by Jesse Yowell in Support Ticket  BBS-49632).

This introduces management issues with our bitbucket.org organisation account. We are managing this bitbucket organisation with a group of admins. Due to the fact that a app password is always defined at user-level other admins are not able to review and revoke app passwords one admin has defined (in his user account). Sharing account credentials is not an option to us.

We consider this management issue a conceptional bug - therefore this issue is a bug.
fields.summary: Deprecation of the 'Team API Key' feature introduces management issues

fields.description: At the moment a user can see that there is a app password is defined but he can not see, what permissions are permitted by this app password. Please add a "view" and a "edit" function for each app password.
fields.summary: 'app passwords' feature: improve reviewing of existing app passwords

fields.description:
While Atlassian is free to remove a feature or to deprecate a feature, tt seams that there was no 'deprecation period or it is a lot to short'. (packagist.com was launched in Dec. 2016 and this feature disappeared before end of Feb. 2017). This deprecation seams to not effect older accounts, as a packagist co-founder confirmed.

Please enable this menu point for new accounts, too (and place a deprecation warning),\\
to give all users and integration partners enough time to miragte to app passwords.
fields.summary: Deprecating 'Team API key' feature breakes integration with packagist.com
